description: Breastfeeding protects babies and young children against dangerous illnesses.
title: Breastfeeding protects babies and young children against dangerous illnesses
content:
- Breastmilk protects against illness because it contains antibodies
   that transfer the mother's immunity or resistance to disease to the
   child. No other milks contain these antibodies.

 - Breastmilk is a baby's 'first immunization'. It helps to protect
   against diarrhoea, ear and chest infections, and other health
   problems.

 - The protection is greatest when breastmilk alone is given for the
   first 6 months and when breastfeeding continues along with other
   foods well into the second year and beyond.

 - No other milks, foods or supplements can provide the protection of
   breastmilk.
